member.name: T:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader
member.summary:
This is used to read SNP items from a text reader available as character separated values in a line. There is one SNP item per line and each line has four character separated fields whose column numbers are identified: a chromosome number, the Position, and the two allele values that are valid for that SNP. There may be assitional columns too, but their values are ignored.
Classes that extend from this can override the protected properties and virtual methods to perform Snp file format specific transformations before returning the field values.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.IsChromosomeSorted
member.summary: If true, the chromosome numbers are assumed to be sorted when SkipToChromosome* methods are called.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.IsChromosomePositionSorted
member.summary: If true, the chromosome numbers AND chromosome positions within them are assumed to be sorted when SkipToChromosome* methods are called.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.currentSnpItem
member.summary: The SNP item that has been parsed for the current line

member.name: F:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.isFirstLine
member.summary: True if the current line contains the first line read from the reader

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.#ctor(System.IO.TextReader,System.Char[],System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a SNP reader from the given text reader that has character separated values for Snpitems.
member.param: Source text reader for the SNP lines
Valid character separators between fields in the line e.g. '\t', ',', etc.
If true, trims the white space around a field value
If true, treats the field values of the first line in the text reader as a header with the names of the fields.
The zero-based column number in a line that corresponds to the chromosome field
The zero-based column number in a line that corresponds to the Snp position field
The zero-based column number in a line that corresponds to the first allele
The zero-based column number in a line that corresponds to the second allele

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.MoveNext
member.summary: Go to the next line in the text reader, unless it is the first line in which case, it has already been called by MBFTextReader in the constructor and we do not move the TextReader.
member.returns: True if we have a valid SnpItem in the next line moved to

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.Reset
member.summary: This method is not implemented for XsvSnpReader. Use BufferedSnpReader() instead.
member.exception: Thrown always since this method is not supported by this class

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.SkipToChromosome(System.Int32)
member.summary: This moves the cursor to the current/next SNP item containing the given chromosome number (i.e. Current.Chromosome == chromosomeNumber), or beyond the end of the enumerator if none exist. This is useful when traversing sorted SNP sequences and we need to jump to a specific chromosome number. The enumerator should be positioned at or after the first item and at or before the last item.
member.param: The chromosome number for the Snpitem to move to.
member.returns: True if the cursor was moved to a SnpItem with the given chromosome number. False if no subsequent SnpItems exist with given chromosome number. If returning true, the Current item will have given chromosome number.
member.exception: The enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection or after the last element.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.SkipToChromosomePosition(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This moves the cursor to the current/next SNP item containing the given chromosome number and position (i.e. Current.Chromosome == chromosomeNumber and Current.Position == position), or beyond the end of the enumerator if none exist. The enumerator should be positioned at or after the first item and at or before the last item. NOTE: This is useful when traversing sorted SNP sequences and need to jump to a specific chromosome number+position.
member.param: The chromosome number for the Snpitem to move to.
The position within chromosome number for the Snpitem to move to.
member.returns: Returns true if a SnpItem with given chromosome number and position is found. If end of file is reached before this they are found, it returns false. If returning true, the Current item will have given chromosome number and position.
member.exception: The enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection or after the last element.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvSnpReader.SkipToChromosomePosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: This moves the cursor to the current/next SNP item containing the current chromosome number and position equal to the given position (i.e. Current.Position == position and Current.Chromosome does not change), or beyond the end of the enumerator if none exist. The enumerator should be positioned at or after the first item and at or before the last item. NOTE: This is useful when traversing sorted SNP sequences and need to jump to a specific chromosome position within current chromosome position.
member.param: The position within chromosome number for the Snpitem to move to.
member.returns: Returns true if this position is found. False if the next chromosome number is encountered, or end of file is reached before the position is found. If returning true, the Current item will contain the starting chromosome number and given position.
member.exception: The enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection or after the last element.

member.param: field name enumerator to get the string value for
member.returns: Returns the field value as a string for the given field enum.

member.name: T:MBF.Complementation
member.summary: Provides DNA and RNA nucleotide complements.
member.remarks: Nucleotide complements are bases that bond with, and correspond to one another. For the DNA case, the correspondence is generally at a common location on the two strands of a DNA double helix. For RNA, the single strand can overlap and bond with itself in various ways to create secondary structure, and complementation will determine where this can happen. Static methods in the class provide lookup for single nucleotide complements, as well as creating the complementary strand for a given DNA sequence.

member.name: M:MBF.Complementation.GetDnaComplement(MBF.Nucleotide)
member.summary: Returns the complement of a DNA nucleotide. This also respects ambiguous characters in the DNA alphabet.

member.name: M:MBF.Complementation.GetRnaComplement(MBF.Nucleotide)
member.summary: Returns the complement of an RNA nucleotide. This also respects ambiguous characters in the RNA alphabet.

member.name: M:MBF.Complementation.Complement(MBF.ISequence)
member.summary: Transcribes a DNA sequence into the corresponding sequence on the other strand (which will have the opposite orientation). The length of the resulting sequence will equal the length of the source sequence. Gap and ambiguous characters will also be transcribed.
member.returns: A new complementary sequence.

member.name: M:MBF.Complementation.ReverseComplement(MBF.ISequence)
member.summary:
Transcribes a DNA sequence into the corresponding sequence on the other strand, then reverses it so that the new sequence has the same orientation as the original (in the 3'-to-5' sense). The length of the resulting sequence will equal the length of the source sequence. Gap and ambiguous characters will also be transcribed.
For example:
Sequence dna = new Sequence(Alphabets.DNA, "TACCGC"); Sequence otherStrand = Complementarity.ReverseComplement(dna);
otherStrand.ToString() would produce "GCGGTA"
member.returns: A new complementary sequence.

member.summary: Returns random numbers according to an approximate normal distribution with an average and standard deviation set by the caller.
member.param: Average result returned from calling the method
Standard deviation applied to the normal curve
member.returns: A random value

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Helper.GetNormalRandom(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns random numbers according to an approximate normal distribution with an average and standard deviation set by the caller. This is done iteratively using the central limit theorem.
member.param: Average result returned from calling the method
Standard deviation applied to the normal curve

The number of iterative steps to take in generating each number. The higher this number is, the closer to a true normal distribution the results will be, but the higher the computation cost. A value between 4 and 8 should be sufficient for most uses.
member.returns: A random value

member.summary: Copy constructor.
member.param: The sequence statistics to copy from.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.GetCount(System.Char)
member.summary:
Gets the number of occurences of a specific symbol. This method does not perform any calculations to group counts of ambiguous symbols with corresponding unambiguous symbols. So the minimum G-C content of a DNA sequence would be calculated as
GetCount('G') + GetCount('C') + GetCount('S')
member.param: The char representation of a symbol.
member.returns: The number of occurences of the given symbol.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.GetCount(MBF.ISequenceItem)
member.summary:
Gets the number of occurences of the specific sequence item. This method does not perform any calculations to group counts of ambiguous symbols with corresponding unambiguous symbols. So the minimum G-C content of a DNA sequence would be calculated as
GetCount('G') + GetCount('C') + GetCount('S')
member.returns: The number of occurences of the given sequence item.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.GetFraction(System.Char)
member.summary:
Gets the fraction of occurences of a specific symbol. This method does not perform any calculations to group counts of ambiguous symbols with corresponding unambiguous symbols. So the minimum G-C content of a DNA sequence would be calculated as
GetFraction('G') + GetFraction('C') + GetFraction('S')
member.param: The char representation of a symbol.
member.returns: The fraction of occurences of the given symbol.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.GetFraction(MBF.ISequenceItem)
member.summary:
Gets the fraction of occurences of a specific sequence item. This method does not perform any calculations to group counts of ambiguous symbols with corresponding unambiguous symbols. So the minimum G-C content of a DNA sequence would be calculated as
GetFraction('G') + GetFraction('C') + GetFraction('S')
member.returns: The fraction of occurences of the given sequence item.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Adds the counts of the symbols in the given string to the existing counts.

member.name: M:MBF.SequenceStatistics.Add(System.Char)
member.summary: Increments the count of the given symbol.

member.name: T:MBF.Sequence
member.summary:
This is the standard implementation of the ISequence interface. It contains the raw data that defines the contents of a sequence. You can access that data in two ways. The first is by treating the Sequence as a list of SequenceItems. For example:
Sequence mySequence = new Sequence(Alphabets.DNA, "GATTC"); foreach (Nucleotide nucleotide in mySequence) { ... }
You can also retrieve the data and work with it as a string. For example:
String nucleotides = mySequence.ToString();
In both cases the results will be based on the Alphabet associated with the sequence. Common alphabets include those for DNA, RNA, and Amino Acids.
For users who wish to get at the underlying data directly, Sequence provides a means to do this as well. This may be useful for those writing algorithms against the sequence where performance is especially important. For these advanced users access is provided to the encoding classes associated with the sequence.
This class is marked with Serializable attribute thus instances of this class can be serialized and stored to files and the stored files can be de-serialized to restore the instances.
This class also used by Data Virtualization on editable and non-editable scenario

member.name: M:MBF.Sequence.#ctor(MBF.IAlphabet)
member.summary:
Creates a sequence with no sequence data and sets IsReadOnly property of the created sequence to false.
For working with sequences that never have sequence data, but are only used for metadata storage (like keeping an ID or various features but no direct sequence data) consider using the VirtualSequence class instead.
member.param: The alphabet the sequence uses (eg. Alphabets.DNA or Alphabets.RNA)

member.name: M:MBF.Sequence.#ctor(MBF.IAlphabet,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.param: The alphabet the sequence uses (eg. Alphabets.DNA or Alphabets.RNA)
A description of the sequence where each character in the string is known by the alphabet.
Indicates whether encoding is used to store the sequence in memory

member.name: M:MBF.Sequence.#ctor(MBF.IAlphabet,MBF.Encoding.IEncoding,System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a sequence based on sequence data passed in via a string parameter. The characters in the sequence parameter must be contained in the alphabet or an Exception will occur.
This constructor also allows the setting of a particular encoding and is designed for programmers familiar with the encoding techniques used for storing sequence data in memory. Users not familiar with these encodings should consider using the Sequence(IAlphabet, string) constructor instead.
The standard SequenceEncoder for the given encoding is used.
member.param: The alphabet the sequence uses (eg. Alphabets.DNA or Alphabets.RNA)
A description of the sequence where each character in the string is known by the alphabet.
The encoding to use when converting the sequence data into in memory byte represenation. This encoding must have an EncodingMap registered for it and the alphabet via EncodingMaps.GetMapToEncoding().

member.name: M:MBF.Sequence.#ctor(MBF.IAlphabet,MBF.Encoding.IEncoding,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Creates a sequence based on sequence data passed in via a string parameter. The characters in the sequence parameter must be contained in the alphabet or an Exception will occur.
This constructor also allows the setting of a particular encoding and is designed for programmers familiar with the encoding techniques used for storing sequence data in memory. Users not familiar with these encodings should consider using the Sequence(IAlphabet, string) constructor instead.

member.param: The alphabet the sequence uses (eg. Alphabets.DNA or Alphabets.RNA)

The encoding to use when converting the sequence data into in memory byte represenation. This encoding must have an EncodingMap registered for it and the alphabet via EncodingMaps.GetMapToEncoding().

member.name: P:MBF.Sequence.IsReadOnly
member.summary:
A flag indicating whether or not edits can be made to this Sequence. When IsReadOnly is true, the sequence data is stored in a compact array and any method for editing that data will throw an exception. When IsReadOnly is false, the sequence data is stored in a less compact structure that allows for quick edits.
You can set the IsReadOnly flag. The result of doing so will transfer the internal storage of the data from one mechanism to the other.

member.name: T:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver
member.summary:
This is the default implementation of ILocationResolver. This class resolves the start and end positions of a location.
Please see the following table for how this class resolves the ambiguities in start and end data.
Start/End Data Resolved Start Resolved End 12.30 12 30 >30 30 30 <30 30 30 23^24 23 24 100^1 1000 1

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.Clone
member.summary: Returns the new LocationResolver instance that is a copy of this instance.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.GetStart(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation)
member.summary: Returns the start position by resolving the startdata present in the specified location. If unable to resolve startdata then an exception will occur.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.GetEnd(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation)
member.summary: Returns the end position by resolving the enddata present in the specified location. If unable to resolve enddata then an exception will occur.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.GetSubSequence(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation,MBF.ISequence)
member.summary:
Returns a sequence which contains bases from the specified sequence as specified by the location. If the location of a feature and sequence in which the feature is present is specified then this method returns a sequence which contains the bases of the specified feature.
Please note that, 1. If Accession of the location is not null or empty then an exception will occur. 2. If the location contains "order" operator then this method uses SegmentedSequence class to construct the sequence. For example, order(100..200,300..450) will result in a SegmentedSequence which internally contains two sequences, first one created from 100 to 200 bases, and second one created from 300 to 450 bases.
member.param: Sequence from which the sub sequence has to be returned.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.GetSubSequence(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation,MBF.ISequence,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,MBF.ISequence})
member.summary:
Returns a sequence which contains bases from the specified sequence as specified by the location. If the location contains accession then the sequence from the referredSequences which matches the accession of the location will be considered.
For example, if location is "join(100..200, J00089.1:10..50, J00090.2:30..40)" then bases from 100 to 200 will be considered from the sequence parameter and referredSequences will be searched for the J00089.1 and J00090.2 accession if found then those sequences will be considered for constructing the output sequence. If the referred sequence is not found in the referredSequences then an exception will occur.
member.param: Sequence instance from which the sub sequence has to be returned.
A dictionary containing Accession numbers as keys and Sequences as values, this will be used when the location or sublocations contains accession.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.IsInStart(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return true if the specified position is within the start position. For example, if the startdata of a location is "23.40", this method will return true for the position values ranging from 23 to 40.
member.returns: Returns true if the specified position is with in the start position else returns false.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.IsInEnd(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return true if the specified position is within the end position. For example, if the enddata of a location is "23.40", this method will return true for the position values ranging from 23 to 40.
member.returns: Returns true if the specified P\position is with in the end position else returns false.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.GenBank.LocationResolver.IsInRange(MBF.IO.GenBank.ILocation,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified position is with in the start and end positions.
member.returns: Returns true if the specified position is with in the start and end positions else returns false.

member.name: T:MBF.IO.GenBank.Location
member.summary: Location, holds the feature location information. This is the default implementaion of the ILocation interface. This holds Start and End points of location. If in case location refers to some other sequence (for example, J00194.1:1..150) then the accession number information should be stored in the Accession property. Resolver property is used to resolve any ambiguity in the location startdata and enddata. By default this will be set to an instance of LocationResolver class.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMAlignedSequenceHeader.DotSymbolIndices
member.summary: Contains the list of indices of "." symbols present in the aligned sequence. As "." is not supported by DNA, RNA and Protien alphabets, while creating aligned sequence "." symbols are replaced by "N" which has the same meaning of ".".

member.name: P:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMAlignedSequenceHeader.EqualSymbolIndices
member.summary: Contains the list of "=" symbol indices present in the aligned sequence. The "=" symbol in aligned sequence indicates that the symbol at this index is equal to the symbol present in the reference sequence. As "=" is not supported by DNA, RNA and Protien alphabets, while creating aligned sequence "=" symbols are replaced by the symbol present in the reference sequence at the same index.

member.name: T:MBF.Algorithms.SuffixTree.SimpleSuffixTreeBuilder
member.summary: This class implements Algorithm (using Multi-Way Suffix Tree) to build the Suffix Tree. Steps to build the suffix tree are: For every prefix in suffix of sequence string Add prefix to the tree, prefix can be added in to ways 1. New edge is created 2. Previous edge is updated (split the tree and and new edges)

member.name: T:MBF.IO.XsvContigFormatter
member.summary: This class will write a contig as a list of sparse sequences using the XsvSparseFormatter. The first sequence is the consensus, and the rest are the assembled sequences offset from the consensus. E.g. formatting a Contig with 2 assembled sequences, using '#' as sequence prefix and ',' as character separator. # 0,100,Consensus 12,A 29,T 39,G #3,10,Fragment1 9,A #25,20,Fragment2 4,T 14,G

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvContigFormatter.#ctor(System.Char,System.Char)
member.summary: Creates a formatter for contigs using the given separator and sequence start line prefix characacter.
member.param: The character to separate position of the sequence item from its symbol, and separate the offset, count and sequence ID in the sequence start line.
The character to refix the sequence start line.

member.name: M:MBF.IO.XsvContigFormatter.Format(MBF.Algorithms.Assembly.Contig,System.IO.TextWriter)
member.summary: Formats a (sparse) contig to a charcter separated value file, writing the consensus first, followed by the sequence separator, and each assembled sequences followed by the sequence separator. The consensus has an offet of 0, while the assembed sequences have the offset as present in AssembledSequence.Position.
member.param: The contig to format as a set of sparse sequences.
The text writer to write the formatted output to.

member.name: T:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Transcription
member.summary: Provides basic nucleotide transcription across DNA and RNA sequences. Static methods in the class provide lookup for single nucleotide complements as well as creating RNA (transcription) or DNA (reverse transcription) from a DNA or RNA sequence, respectively.

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Transcription.GetRnaComplement(MBF.Nucleotide)
member.summary: Returns the complement nucleotide from DNA to RNA. This also respects ambiguous characters in the DNA and RNA alphabet.

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Transcription.GetDnaComplement(MBF.Nucleotide)
member.summary: Returns the complement nucleotide from RNA to DNA. This also respects ambiguous characters in the DNA and RNA alphabet.

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Transcription.Transcribe(MBF.ISequence)
member.summary:
Transcribes a DNA sequence into an RNA sequence. The length of the resulting sequence will equal the length of the source sequence. Gap and ambiguous characters will also be transcribed.
For example:
Sequence dna = new Sequence(Alphabets.DNA, "TACCGC"); Sequence rna = Transcription.Transcribe(dna);
rna.ToString() would produce "AUGGCG"

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Transcription.ReverseTranscribe(MBF.ISequence)
member.summary:
Does reverse transcription from an RNA sequence into an DNA sequence. The length of the resulting sequence will equal the length of the source sequence. Gap and ambiguous characters will also be transcribed.
For example:
Sequence rna = new Sequence(Alphabets.RNA, "UACCGC"); Sequence dna = Transcription.ReverseTranscribe(rna);
dna.ToString() would produce "ATGGCG"

member.name: T:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Codons
member.summary:
A class which stores a table of mappings from triplets of RNA nucleotides to Amino Acids. This mapping comes from the standard Axiom of Genetics triplet rule. This class provides the basic lookup functionality from the codons. The ProteinTranslation class provides methods for translating whole RNA sequences.
In order to perform mapping from DNA, it is suggested that you first use the Transcription class to create the RNA sequence

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Codons.Lookup(MBF.Nucleotide,MBF.Nucleotide,MBF.Nucleotide)
member.summary: Lookup an amino acid based on a triplet of nucleotides. U U U for instance will result in Phenylalanine.

member.name: M:MBF.Algorithms.Translation.Codons.Lookup(MBF.ISequence,System.Int32)
member.summary: Lookup an amino acid within a sequence starting a certian offset.
member.param: The source sequence to lookup from.

The offset within the sequence from which to look at the next three nucleotides. Note that this offset begins its count at zero. Thus looking at a sequence described by "AUGGCG" and using a offset of 0 would lookup the amino acid for codon "AUG" while using a offset of 1 would lookup the amino acid for codon "UGG".
member.returns: An amino acid from the protein alphabet

member.name: T:MBF.Matrix.RenameColsView`3
member.summary: A wrapper around a parent matrix that allows col keys to be renamed and/or expanded. If expanded, then multiple keys will point to the same underlying row, meaning change to a value in one row will be reflected in another row. Also, because it is a view, any changes made to the values of this matrix or the parent matrix are reflected in both.
member.typeparam: The type of the row key. Usually "String"
The type of the col key. Usually "String"
The type of the value, for example, double, int, char, etc.

member.name: P:MBF.Matrix.RenameColsView`3.ParentMatrix
member.summary: The matrix that this view wraps.

member.name: P:MBF.Matrix.RenameColsView`3.NewKeyToOldKey
member.summary: A read-only dictionary giving the mapping from the col keys of this matrix to the col keys of its parent matrix.

member.name: P:MBF.Matrix.RenameColsView`3.NewIndexToOldIndex
member.summary: A read-only dictionary giving the mapping from the col index of this matrix to the col index of it's parent matrix

member.name: T:MBF.IO.VirtualQualitativeSequenceList
member.summary: A VirtualQualitativeSequenceList is used in data virtualization scenarios to maintain a large list of sequences. When all the available sequences cannot be accommodated at once in memory, this list fetches blocks of sequences from the cache or from the file on request. For example, if a FastA file has more than one sequence and data virtualization returns this class, then each sequence is loaded from the FastA file when it is first accessed.

member.name: T:MBF.IO.Bed.BedParser
member.summary:
Parses ISequenceRange objects that are formatted according to the BED format. This is a format of tab delimited text where the each line represents one range and each defines an ID, start and stop index.
Info for the specification of this format can be found at: http://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat
In this format indices start their count from zero. The chromosome start index is inclusive and the chromosome end index is exclusive.
There are three required fields in each line as described above. There are also 9 option fields. These are: name, score, strand, thickStartm thickEnd, itemRgb, blockCount, blockSizes, and blockStarts.
This parser does not support the bigBED format.

member.name: T:MBF.ByteArray
member.summary:
ByteArray holds the encoded values and provides array like access to the data stored in it. This class internally stores compressed indices of encoded values into a byte array to reduce the memory required to hold sequence data. For example: Ncbi2NAEncoding contains four encoded values to store an index of an encoded value; two bits are sufficient. Thus when creating this class, if Ncbi2NAEncoding is specified, then the index of specified encoded values are stored in a byte array so that each byte will contain a maximum of four encoded values.
Note that data will be compressed when the total number of encoded values present in the specified IEncoding is less than or equal to 16, otherwise it stores specified encoded values in the byte array.

member.name: M:MBF.ByteArray.#ctor(MBF.Encoding.IEncoding,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Byte})
member.summary:
Creates new ByteArray instance from the specified encoding and list of byte values. ByteArray compacts and stores the byte values depending on the specified encoding.
For example: Ncbi2NAEncoding contains four values, In this case two bits are sufficient to store index of an encoded value thus four encoded values can be stored in to a byte.
Note that data will be compressed when the total number of encoded values present in the specified IEncoding is less than or equal to 16, otherwise it stores specified encoded values in the byte array.
member.param: Encoding to which the specified values are belongs to.

member.name: M:MBF.ByteArray.#ctor(MBF.Encoding.IEncoding,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Creates new ByteArray instance from the specified encoding which can store specified size of encoded values. ByteArray compacts and stores the byte values depending on the specified encoding.
For example: Ncbi2NAEncoding contains four values, In this case two bits are sufficient to store index of an encoded value thus four encoded values can be stored in to a byte.
Note that data will be compressed when the total number of encoded values present in the specified IEncoding is less than or equal to 16, otherwise it stores specified encoded values in the byte array.
member.param: Encoding to which the specified values are belongs to.

member.summary: Sets required fields from the specified encoding.

member.summary: Stores specified encoded value.

member.name: M:MBF.ByteArray.GetByteValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the encoded value for the specified index.
member.param: Index of the value to be required.
member.returns: Returns the encoded value.

member.name: M:MBF.ByteArray.GetBitsRequired(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns the number of bits required to store the specified value.
For example if the input value is 3, the number of bits needed to store 3 is 2 bits (Binary - 11). Hence this method would return 2 bits as the output.
member.param: Value for which the number of required bits has to be determined.
member.returns: Number of bits required to store the value.

member.name: M:MBF.ByteArray.GetByteMask(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns mask value that can be used while reading each value present in the compressed byte. Note that position is one based and starts from lefthand side of the byte.
For example: If 2 four bit values, 1011 and 1101 are placed in a byte then the value of byte will be 10111101. Following are the steps to read first value i.e 1011.
Step1: "bitwise AND" with _maskForFirstFourBitValue. 10111101 & 11110000 = 10110000 Step2: Right shift the result from Step1 by 4 position. 10110000 >> 4 = 00001011
member.param: Position of the value in the byte.
Size of each value in bits.
member.returns: Returns the mask value.

member.name: T:MBF.Matrix.TransposeView`3
member.summary: A wrapper around a parent matrix that switches the rows with the columns. Because it is a view, any changes made to the values of this matrix or the parent matrix are reflected in both.
member.typeparam: The type of the row key. Usually "String"
The type of the col key. Usually "String"
The type of the value, for example, double, int, char, etc.

member.name: P:MBF.Matrix.TransposeView`3.ParentMatrix
member.summary: The matrix that this view wraps.

member.name: T:MBF.Matrix.MergeRowsView`3
member.summary: A wrapper around one or more parent matrices that created a merged view of their rows. Because it is a view, any changes made to the values of this matrix or the parents are reflected in all.
member.typeparam: The type of the row key. Usually "String"
The type of the col key. Usually "String"
The type of the value, for example, double, int, char, etc.

member.name: M:MBF.Matrix.MergeRowsView`3.#ctor(System.Boolean,MBF.Matrix.Matrix{`0,`1,`2}[])
member.summary: Creates a new view in which the rows of the matrices are merged. The rows will be in the order of the input matrices. If two matrices contain a rows with the same rowKey, an exception is thrown. All matricies must have the same MissingValue. This is a 'view' in the sense that changes to the values in either matrix will be reflected in both.
member.param: true, to require all matrices to have the same colKeys in the same order; false, use an intersection of the colKeys in the order of ColKeys of the first matrix.
One or more matricies with which to concatinate rows.

member.name: T:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog
member.summary: log is a class that implements straightforward logging to a text file, and tries to minimize clutter of the code that uses it.

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Open(System.String)
member.summary: Opens the specified filename for writing. If the file already exists, it is overwritten. If a different log file is open, it's closed before the new one is opened.

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Reopen(System.String)
member.summary: If log is already open with the same filename, do nothing. Otherwise open (in append mode, if file exists).
member.remarks: Be aware that log files that are never truncated can become very large.

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.OpenAppend(System.String)
member.summary: Open the specified filename (in append mode if it exists).

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Close
member.summary: If a writer is open, flush, close, and dispose it.

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Write a single string to the writer.
member.returns: the string

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Write(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Write a formatted string to the output. Same syntax as Stream.Write().
member.returns: the formatted string that was written

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.WriteLine(System.String)
member.summary: Write a plain string to the output, then a newline.
member.returns: the string

member.summary: Write a formatted string to the output, then a newline. Same syntax as Stream.WriteLine().
member.returns: the formatted string that was written

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.WriteTime(System.String,System.Object[])

member.returns: the formatted string (including date/time) that was written

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Exception(System.Exception)
member.summary: Write an exception's message, its inner exception's message, and the stack trace to the log.
member.returns: the formatted string that was written

member.name: M:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Flush
member.summary: Flush any pending writes

member.name: P:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Autoflush
member.summary: if true (default), a flush occurs after each write, to prevent loss of messages. if false, calling code should Flush() after critical writes.

member.name: P:MBF.Util.Logging.ApplicationLog.Ready
member.summary: returns true if there is a valid writer. if not in this state, writes will be no-ops.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Allele
member.summary: Name of the allele for the given gene. All gene-related features (exon, CDS etc) for a given gene should share the same Allele qualifier value; the Allele qualifier value must, by definition, be different from the Gene qualifier value; when used with the variation feature key, the Allele qualifier value should be that of the variant.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Citation
member.summary: Reference to a citation listed in the entry reference field.

member.summary: Specifies a codon which is different from any found in the reference genetic code.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.CodonStart
member.summary: Indicates the offset at which the first complete codon of a coding feature can be found, relative to the first base of that feature.

member.summary: Database cross-reference: pointer to related information in another database.

member.summary: Enzyme Commission number for enzyme product of sequence.

member.summary: Feature tag assigned for tracking purposes.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Operon
member.summary: Name of the group of contiguous genes transcribed into a single transcript to which that feature belongs.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Product
member.summary: Name of the product associated with the feature, e.g. the mRNA of an mRNA feature, the polypeptide of a CDS, the mature peptide of a mat_peptide, etc.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.ProteinId
member.summary: Protein identifier, issued by International collaborators. this qualifier consists of a stable ID portion (3+5 format with 3 position letters and 5 numbers) plus a version number after the decimal point.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Pseudo
member.summary: Indicates that this feature is a non-functional version of the element named by the feature key.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.RibosomalSlippage
member.summary: During protein translation, certain sequences can program ribosomes to change to an alternative reading frame by a mechanism known as ribosomal slippage.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.StandardName
member.summary: Accepted standard name for this feature.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.Translation
member.summary: Automatically generated one-letter abbreviated amino acid sequence derived from either the universal genetic code or the table as specified in Transl_table qualifier and as determined by exceptions in the Transl_except and Codon qualifiers.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.TranslationalExcept
member.summary: Translational exception: single codon the translation of which does not conform to genetic code defined by Organism and Codon qualifier.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.TranslationTable
member.summary: Definition of genetic code table used if other than universal genetic code table.

member.name: P:MBF.IO.GenBank.CodingSequence.TransSplicing
member.summary: Indicates that exons from two RNA molecules are ligated in intermolecular reaction to form mature RNA.

member.name: T:MBF.IO.GenBank.Attenuator
member.summary: Region of DNA at which regulation of termination of transcription occurs, which controls the expression of some bacterial operons. Sequence segment located between the promoter and the first structural gene that causes partial termination of transcription.

member.name: T:MBF.Matrix.MergeColsView`3
member.summary: A wrapper around one or more parent matrices that created a merged view of their columns. Because it is a view, any changes made to the values of this matrix or the parents are reflected in all.
member.typeparam: The type of the row key. Usually "String"
The type of the col key. Usually "String"
The type of the value, for example, double, int, char, etc.

member.name: M:MBF.Matrix.MergeColsView`3.#ctor(System.Boolean,MBF.Matrix.Matrix{`0,`1,`2}[])
member.summary: Creates a new view in which the cols of the matrices are merged. The cols will be in the order of the input matrices. If two matrices contain a rows with the same colKey, an exception is thrown. All matricies must have the same MissingValue. This is a 'view' in the sense that changes to the values in either matrix will be reflected in both.
member.param: true, to require all matrices to have the same rowKeys in the same order; false, use an intersection of the rowKeys in the order of RowKeys of the first matrix.
One or more matricies with which to concatinate cols.

member.name: T:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags
member.summary: SAM Flags. This enum represents the bitwise flags of the SAM format.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.PairedRead
member.summary: 0x0001 The read is paired in sequencing, no matter whether it is mapped in a pair.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.MappedInProperPair
member.summary: 0x0002 The read is mapped in a proper pair (depends on the protocol, normally inferred during alignment).

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.UnmappedQuery
member.summary: 0x0004 The query sequence itself is unmapped.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.UnmappedMate
member.summary: 0x0008 The mate is unmapped.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.QueryOnReverseStrand
member.summary: 0x0010 Strand of the query (0 for forward; 1 for reverse strand).

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.MateOnReverseStrand
member.summary: 0x0020 Strand of the mate.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.FirstReadInPair
member.summary: 0x0040 The read is the first read in a pair.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.SecondReadInPair
member.summary: 0x0080 The read is the second read in a pair.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.NonPrimeAlignment
member.summary: 0x0100 The alignment is not primary (a read having split hits may have multiple primary alignment records).

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.QualityCheckFailure
member.summary: 0x0200 The read fails platform/vendor quality checks.

member.name: F:MBF.IO.SAM.SAMFlags.Duplicate
member.summary: 0x0400 The read is either a PCR duplicate or an optical duplicate.

member.summary:
Filter mate pairs based on support for contig orientation. The mate pairs support specific orientation of contigs, based on mapping of reverse read or forward read to specify orientation. Orientation 1 ----------) (------------- contig 1 contig 2
Orientation 2 ----------) (-------------
contig 2 contig 1
